choices.text: Contour of greater trochanter is normal
Some patient might be able to walk with this fracture
Shortening is more as compared to IT femur fracture

questions.text: A 65 yr old lady slipped and fell in the bathroom and sustained a fracture in right hip. X Ray is as follows, select false statements.
questions.solution:
Mnemonic: All Findings are less / Mild in Neck of femur fracture.

Clinical Features of neck femur fracture:

  • Presentation:
    • Occasionally, patients may arrive walking with only mild groin pain. (Option C)
    • More commonly, elderly patients present with:
      • Pain in the groin.
      • Inability to move the limb or bear weight following a minor injury (e.g., slipping or missing a step).
    • Symptoms:
      • Pain: Mild or absent in some cases. (Option B)
      • Swelling: Minimal or absent.
      • Diagnosis may be missed for days or weeks due to the subtlety of symptoms.
  • Clinical Examination Findings:
    • External Rotation of the Leg: The leg appears rotated outward, with the patella facing outward.
    • Shortening of the Leg: Slight shortening may be observed. (Option D)
    • Tenderness in the groin over scarpa's triangle. (Option A)
    • Painful Hip Movements: Attempted movements cause severe pain and muscle spasm.
    • Inability to Perform Active Straight Leg Raising.

Key takeaway:

  • Although both fracture neck femur and intertrochanteric fracture presents with similar signs, inter-trochanteric fractures typically exhibit more pronounced symptoms and clinical signs like pain, shortening and external rotation.

questions.text: Most commonly injured nerve in the fracture pattern given in x ray is?
questions.solution:
The fracture pattern shown in x ray is Monteggia fracture dislocation.

Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) Injury

  • Association with Injuries:
    • Dislocation of the radial head.
    • Fracture of the shaft of the ulna (Monteggia lesion). (Option D)
    • Fracture of the olecranon.
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Stretch or Compression:
      • At the radial neck.
      • Under the supinator muscle.
    • Direct Damage:
      • More distal injury resulting from ulna fractures.
  • Recovery and Management:
  • Spontaneous Recovery
  • Intervention: Exploration and decompression of the nerve may be necessary if there is no evidence of recovery after 8 weeks.

Option A - AIN nerve injury rarely occurs. Seldom seen in complex trauma cases.

Option B - Commonly injured around elbow in distal humerus complex fractures.

Option C - Axillary nerve injury is associated with proximal humerus fractures.

Key takeaways:

  • Closed reduction and casting of Monteggia fractures should be reserved only for the pediatric population.
  • Monteggia fractures require operative treatment as it’s usually associated with PIN Injury, open reduction, and internal fixation of the ulna shaft with a plate is done.
  • After fixation of the ulna, the radial head is usually stable (>90%).

choices.text: Due to injury to the FDP tendon
Sudden passive flexion at DIP causes this condition
Due to injury to EDC tendon

questions.text: Select false statement about the condition shown in this image:
questions.solution:
Mallet Finger (Baseball Finger)

Overview:

  • Cause: Sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint (Option C) causing avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon (Option D) from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx. May also include a fragment of bone.
  • Clinical Presentation: Distal phalanx remains in slight flexion.
  • Treatment: Immobilize the DIP joint in hyperextension using an aluminum splint or plaster cast.

Nonoperative Treatment:

  • Timing: Effective if detected within 12 weeks of injury.
  • Protocol:
    • DIP joint extension splinting for 6 weeks.
    • Follow-up with part-time splinting for an additional 4–6 weeks.
  • Splinting: No proven best type; avoid hyperextension to prevent skin necrosis.
  • PIP Joint Maintenance: Often overlooked but important.

Chronic Mallet Finger (>12 Weeks Post-Injury):

  • Closed Treatment: If the joint is supple, congruent, and without arthritic changes.
  • Dynamic Splinting + Serial Casting: For contracted joints.
  • Operative Treatment:
    • Tenodermodesis.
    • Fowler Tenotomy.

Option A: Its avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx. So Due to injury to the FDP tendon is a False statement.

  • Rugby finger (jersy finger) - flexor tendon rupture result in persistant extension

Key takeaways:

  • Mallet finger (Baseball finger) results from the sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint so that the extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint is avulsed from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx with or without bone piece.
  • Rugby finger (jersy finger) - flexor tendon rupture result in persistant extension

questions.text: A 33 yr old man fell on an outstretched hand and sustained scaphoid waist fracture. All of these are known complication of scaphoid fracture except:
questions.solution:
Option D – CTS is not a known complication of scaphoid waist fractures.

Complications of Scaphoid Fractures

  1. Avascular Necrosis (Option A)
    • Description:
      • The scaphoid has a precarious blood supply.
      • In fractures through the waist, there is a high risk of the proximal fragment becoming avascular.
    • Symptoms:
      • Patients report pain and weakness in the wrist.
    • Radiological Findings:
      • X-rays show non-union of the fracture with sclerosis and crushing of the proximal pole.
  2. Delayed and Non-Union (Option C)
    • Description:
      • A significant percentage of scaphoid fractures may lead to delayed or non-union due to factors such as:
        • Imperfect immobilization.
        • Synovial fluid hindering the formation of a fibrinous bridge.
        • Impaired blood supply to the fragments.
      • Diagnosis:
        • X-rays reveal:
          • Delayed Union: Persistent fracture line after 4-6 months.
          • Non-Union: Features include:
            • Rounding of fracture surfaces.
            • Sharply defined fracture line.
            • Cystic changes in one or both fragments.
            • Late cases may show signs of wrist osteoarthritis (e.g., joint space reduction, osteophyte formation).
  3. Wrist Osteoarthritis (Option B)
    • Description:
      • Osteoarthritis may develop as a result of avascular necrosis or non-union in some scaphoid fractures.

Key takeaways -

Known complications of scaphoid fractures are:

  • AVN
  • Delayed union
  • Non union
  • Wrist arthritis
  • Malunion (rarely)

choices.text: Fracture of upper third radius shaft with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint
Fracture of lower third radius shaft with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint
Fracture of upper third ulna shaft with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint
Fracture of lower third ulna shaft with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint

questions.text: Galeazzi fracture dislocation is best described by:
questions.solution:
Galeazzi Fracture-Dislocation

Description

  • The Galeazzi fracture-dislocation is characterized by:
    • Fracture: Lower third of the radius.
    • Dislocation/Subluxation: Distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • Common Cause: Typically results from a fall on an outstretched hand.

Displacement

  • Fracture Characteristics:
    • The radius fracture is angulated medially and anteriorly.
  • Joint Disruption:
    • The distal radio-ulnar joint is disrupted, leading to dorsal dislocation of the distal end of the ulna.

Diagnosis

  • In cases of isolated fractures of the distal half of the radius, a thorough evaluation of the distal radio-ulnar joint is essential to check for subluxation or dislocation.

Treatment

  • Importance of Reduction:
    • Perfect reduction is crucial for complete restoration of forearm function, particularly rotation.
  • Surgical Intervention:
    • Most adults require open reduction and internal fixation of the radius using a plate.
    • The dislocated radio-ulnar joint may Require open reduction.

Complications

  • Malunion:
    • Can occur due to displacement of the fracture fragment.
    • Leads to:
      • Deformity.
      • Limitation of supination and pronation.

Option C – Fracture of proximal shaft ulna with Proximal radio-ulnar joint dislocation is seen in Monteggia fracture dislocation.

Key takeaways:

Galleazzi fracture dislocation is the counterpart of the Monteggia fracture-dislocation. Here, there is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint. It commonly results from a fall on an outstretched hand.

choices.text: Avulsion sign seen in a TFL injury
Gissane sign seen in calcaneal fracture
Hawkins's sign seen in talar neck fracture
Fleck sign seen in injury at the Lisfranc joint

questions.text: Identify the radiological sign pathognomonic of this foot injury.
questions.solution:
Lisfranc (Tarsometatarsal) Joint Injuries

Epidemiology

  • Rare injuries, often missed (20% initially overlooked).
  • High incidence in polytraumatized patients.

Mechanism of Injury

  1. Twisting: Forceful abduction of the forefoot; seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  2. Axial Loading: Force applied to a fixed foot; e.g., a heavy object striking the heel.
  3. Crushing: Common in industrial injuries; can lead to compartment syndrome.

Clinical Evaluation

  • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, tenderness on dorsum of foot; pathognomonic plantar ecchymosis.
  • Requires high suspicion; 20% are misdiagnosed.
  • Watch for potential complications like compartment syndrome or neurovascular damage.
  • Stress testing (forefoot abduction/pronation) helps diagnose instability.

Radiographic Evaluation

  • Standard AP, lateral, and oblique X-rays typically diagnostic.
  • Key signs: Misalignment of the second metatarsal, dorsal displacement, "flake fractures." (Option D)
  • Weight-bearing and stress views, CT, and MRI may be needed for complex cases.

Treatment

  • Nonoperative: For stable, non-displaced injuries; involves casting or boots and gradual weight bearing.
  • Operative: For displacements >2 mm; involves anatomic reduction and fixation (screws/K-wires).
    • Postoperative care includes immobilization and gradual weight-bearing.

Postoperative Management

  • Immobilization for 6–8 weeks, followed by progressive weight bearing.
  • Removal of lateral column stabilization at 6–12 weeks; medial fixation may remain longer.

Complications

  • Posttraumatic arthritis, compartment syndrome, infection, CRPS, neurovascular injury, hardware failure.
  • Management includes orthotics, arthrodesis, or inter positional arthroplasty for severe cases.

Option A, B & C: Avulsion sign - aTFL injury(An avulsion sign of an anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) injury is an irregular bone fragment in the lateral malleolus),

Gissane sign - calcaneal fracture &

Hawkins's sign -  talar neck fracture all 3 are correct statements.

Key Takeaway:

Fractures & Signs:

Avulsion sign - aTFL injury

Gissane sign - calcaneal fractures

Hawkins's sign - talar neck fracture

Fleck sign - Misalignment of the second metatarsal, dorsal displacement.

questions.text: Piano key sign which is one of the important signs in wrist examination is positive in which condition?
questions.solution:
Components of the Triangular Fibrocartilage Complex (TFCC)

  • Dorsal and Volar Radioulnar Ligaments
  • Articular Disc
  • Meniscus Homologue
  • Extensor Carpi Ulnaris (ECU)
  • Ulnolunate Ligament
  • Ulnotriquetral Ligament

Variance and Load Distribution

  • Neutral Variance:
    • 80% of compressive loads through the radius
    • 20% through the ulna
  • +2 mm Variance:
    • 60% of loads through the radius
    • 40% through the ulna

TFCC Tears

  • Acute (Class I) Tears:
    • Most commonly avulsions at the ulnar periphery (Type IB)
    • These tears are amenable to repair due to well-vascularized periphery.
  • Degenerative (Class II) Tears:
    • Associated with positive ulnar variance and ulnocarpal impaction syndrome.

Diagnosis and Surgical Treatment

  • Arthroscopy:
    • Gold standard for diagnosis of TFCC tears and ulnar-sided wrist pain.
  • Repair Techniques:
    • No clear clinical outcome difference between open and arthroscopic repair techniques.
    • Surgical treatment options:
      • Peripheral Repair: For acute tears.
      • Central Débridement: For specific cases.

Treatment for Variance-Related Conditions

  • Ulnar Shortening Osteotomy: Recommended when no arthrosis is present.
  • Wafer Resection: Indicated for cases with arthrosis.

Management of Chronic and Osteoarthritis Conditions

  • Chronic DRUJ Instability: Treated with TFCC repair or ligament reconstruction.
  • DRUJ Osteoarthritis (OA):
    • Options include:
      • Hemiresection interposition arthroplasty
      • Darrach resection (suitable for low-demand patients)
      • Sauvé-Kapandji arthrodesis (e.g., for rheumatoid arthritis)
      • Prosthetic arthroplasty

Complications

  • Most Common Complication: Injury to superficial sensory nerves.

Option B, C and D: They do not have a positive piano key sign.

The Piano-Key Sign Test is a test carried out for the clinical assessment of wrist instability. It is used as an indicator for distal radio-ulnar joint instability and tears of the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)of the wrist.

Key takeaways:

  • The Piano-Key Sign Test is a test carried out for the clinical assessment of wrist instability. It is used as an indicator for distal radio-ulnar joint instability and tears of the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC)of the wrist.
  • The piano-key test involves depressing the distal ulna from dorsal to volar with the hand pronated. A positive result is characterized by painful laxity in the affected wrist compared with the contralateral wrist.

questions.text: A 31 yr biker sustained tibia midshaft fracture (displaced) after an RTA. All of the following orthopaedic implants can be used to treat this fracture surgically except:
questions.solution:
Operative Modalities for Tibia Shaft Fractures

  1. Intramedullary (IM) Nailing
    • Advantages:
      • Preserves periosteal blood supply and minimizes soft tissue damage.
      • Provides control over alignment, translation, and rotation.
      • Suitable for most fracture patterns.
    • Types:
      • Locked Nail: (Option B)
        • Offers rotational control.
        • Prevents shortening in comminuted fractures or those with significant bone loss.
        • Interlocking screws can be removed later to promote fracture healing (dynamization).
      • Non-locked Nail:
        • Allows impaction at fracture site with weight-bearing.
        • Limited rotational control, rarely used.
  2. Flexible Nails (Enders, Rush Rods) (Option C)
    • Exert spring force to resist angulation and rotation with minimal medullary circulation damage.
    • Indications:
      • Rarely used in the U.S. except in:
        • Children or adolescents with open physes.
        • Adults with exceptionally narrow canals.
  3. External Fixation (Option D)

    • Indications:
      • Severe open fractures, compartment syndrome, head injury, or burns.
      • Reduced use in the U.S. due to the preference for reamed nails in open fractures.
    • Outcomes:
      • Union rates up to 90%, with an average union time of 3.6 months.
      • Pin tract infection rate: 10%–15%.

Option A - K-wire is a very weak implant and is usually used for small bones of hands/feet and temporary reduction in large bones.

Option B, C & D: IM locking nail, TENS nail & Illizarov's external fixator all are used in tibia mid shaft fractures.

Key takeaways -

Implant options to treat tibia midshaft fractures surgically are:

  • IM locking nail (most common)
  • Plates
  • IM non locking nails (Ender's nail, TENS, Rush rods etc.)
  • External fixators (Simple/Illizarov's – Usually used in open fractures/non unions)

choices.text: Can be seen in axial view of xray

questions.text: A labourer fell from 2 meter height and sustained calcaneus fracture. Select true statement about the Bohler's angle in fractures of calcaneum.
questions.solution:
Radiographic Evaluation of Calcaneus Fractures

Initial Radiographic Views

  1. Lateral View of the Hindfoot
  2. Anteroposterior (AP) View of the Foot
  3. Harris Axial View
  4. Ankle Series

Lateral Radiograph

  • Böhler Angle: (Option C)
    • Description: Formed by a line from the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus to the highest point of the posterior facet, and another line from the posterior facet to the superior edge of the tuberosity.
    • Normal Range: 20 to 40 degrees.
    • Clinical Significance: A decrease in this angle indicates collapse of the weight-bearing posterior facet of the calcaneus, shifting body weight anteriorly. (Option A, D)
  • Gissane (Crucial) Angle: (Option B)
    • Description: Formed by two cortical struts—one along the lateral margin of the posterior facet and the other anterior to the calcaneal beak.
    • Normal Range: 105 to 135 degrees.
    • Clinical Significance: An increase in this angle indicates collapse of the posterior facet.

Key takeaways -

  • Bohler's angle can be seen in lateral view of x ray calcaneus.
  • Bohler's angle decreases in intra-articular fractures. Normal 20-40 degrees.
  • Criticalcrucial angle of Gissane Increases in calcaneus fractures. Normal 120-145 degrees.

choices.text: Dynamic views of radial and ulnar deviations of the wrist
Single digital view of the small finger

questions.text: A collegiate field hockey player presents to your clinic with persistent pain over the ulnar side of his palm after an injury during a recent game. In addition to standard radiographs of his hand and wrist, which view(s) should be requested to evaluate a potential cause of his pain?
questions.solution:
Hook of Hamate Fracture

Overview

  • Mechanism of Injury: Commonly results from blunt trauma to the palm, often associated with sports involving impact or repetitive motion, such as golf, baseball, hockey, and racquet sports.

Imaging

  • Carpal Tunnel Radiographic View: Initial imaging modality to assess the hook of hamate.
  • Computed Tomography (CT): Provides detailed visualization of the fracture

Treatment

  • Initial Management: Trial of cast immobilization.
  • Surgical Intervention: Fragment excision is recommended for symptomatic patients if conservative treatment fails.

Complications

  • Flexor Tendon Rupture: May occur in the ring or small finger in cases of chronic nonunion of the fracture.

Option A – Used to see scapho-lunate diastasis in dynamic DISI.

Option B - The carpal tunnel view demonstrates the hook of the hamate. Thus Option B is true.

Option C – Ulnar deviation view is used for scaphoid fractures.

Option D – Single digital view of little finger is used in little finger trauma cases.

Key takeaways:

  • Bipartite Hamate: A congenital variation characterized by a smooth cortical surface, which can be mistaken for a fracture. It is essential for the examiner to differentiate this anatomical variant from an actual fracture to avoid misdiagnosis.

choices.text: Represents a bony avulsion that will likely necessitate pin fixation for stability

Represents displacement of the torn ulnar collateral ligament superficial to the adductor aponeurosis, which can prevent proper healing of the ligament back to the insertion site and will likely necessitate surgical intervention
Represents an area of a chronic nonunion that will likely necessitate open reduction and screw fixation
Represents an incidental radiographic finding that has no clinical relevance

questions.text: After injury to the thumb MCP joint ulnar collateral ligament, what is the significance of a Stener lesion?
questions.solution:
Thumb Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) Joint Dislocation

Anatomy and Mechanism of Injury

  • The thumb MCP joint primarily facilitates flexion and extension but also allows for abduction-adduction and limited rotational movement (pronation with flexion).
  • Collateral Ligament Injury:
    • A one-sided collateral ligament injury can cause the phalanx to subluxate volarly in a rotatory manner, pivoting around the intact opposite ligament.
    • Ulnar Collateral Ligament (UCL) Injury:
      • May present as a two-level injury with a fracture at the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx and a ruptured ligament detached from the fracture fragment.

Stener Lesion (Option A,B,C and D)

  • Definition: The proximal edge of the adductor aponeurosis forms the anatomic basis of the Stener lesion.
    • The torn UCL stump displaced dorsally to the adductor aponeurosis, preventing natural healing to its anatomic insertion at the volar, ulnar base of the proximal phalanx.
  • Incidence: The true incidence of the Stener lesion is unclear due to varied reporting in literature.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical Assessment:
    • If the MCP joint opens >30 degrees or >15 degrees compared to the contralateral side (tested at 30 degrees of flexion), it suggests a complete collateral ligament injury.

Treatment

  1. Nonoperative Management:
    • Indicated for partial collateral ligament injuries.
    • Options:
      • Thumb spica cast or splint for 6 weeks.
  2. Operative Management:
    • Indicated for complete UCL injuries, while surgical management for radial collateral ligament injuries is controversial.
    • Surgical Techniques:
      • Ligament Repair: Using a bone suture anchor.
      • Chronic Injury: If the ligament is not viable for repair, a free tendon graft through bone tunnels may be used.

Key takeaways:

Stener lesion: Occurs in 85% of complete UCL tear injuries when the adductor pollicis aponeurosis is interposed between the avulsed UCL and its insertion site on the base of the proximal phalanx.

  • Treatment: Surgical reattachment of ligament through drill holes, suture anchor, or interference screw is necessary and can't be treated conservatively.

questions.text: A 22-year-old football player sustained an injury to left thumb. Radiographic evaluation shows a Bennett fracture at the base of his thumb. Which muscle provides the predominant deforming force?
questions.solution:
Bennett Fracture

Overview

  • Definition: A Bennett fracture is an intraarticular fracture-dislocation of the base of the first metacarpal bone (see Fig. 7.26).
  • Pathophysiology: Characterized by a single large volar-ulnar fragment that remains attached to the trapezium via the anterior oblique or “beak” ligament, while the remainder of the metacarpal shaft is displaced.

Deforming Forces

  • Abductor Pollicis Longus (APL): Option A
    • Pulls the metacarpal shaft proximally, dorsally, and radially.
    • Causes supination and adduction of the metacarpal shaft.
  • Thumb Extensors: Option C
    • Contribute to the proximal and dorsal displacement of the metacarpal shaft.

Treatment Options

  • Closed Reduction and Percutaneous Pinning (CRPP):
    • Indicated for small or minimally displaced fragments.
  • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF):
    • Recommended for larger fragments or when adequate reduction cannot be achieved through closed means.

Reduction Technique

  • Steps:
    1. Apply traction to the thumb.
    2. Perform palmar abduction.
    3. Induce pronation of the metacarpal shaft.
  • Goal: Achieve less than 1–2 mm of articular step-off to restore joint congruity and minimize the risk of post-traumatic arthritis.

Key takeaways -

Bennett fracture: Intraarticular fracture-dislocation 1st metacarpal base

  • Deforming forces: Abductor pollicis longus (APL) and thumb extensors cause proximal, dorsal, and radial displacement of the metacarpal shaft.
  • APL causes supination and adduction of the metacarpal shaft.
  • Anterior oblique or “beak” ligament keeps the volar-ulnar base fragment reduced to the trapezium.
  • Treatment: CRPP (percutaneous pinning) or ORIF based on the size of fragment

choices.text: Olecranon, elbow dislocation (LCL injury), radial head
Olecranon, elbow dislocation (LCL injury), medial collateral ligament
Medial collateral ligament,elbow dislocation (LCL injury), radial head
Coronoid, elbow dislocation (LCL injury), radial head

questions.text: What three injuries make up the "terrible triad" of the elbow?
questions.solution:
Elbow Dislocation

Overview

  • Most Common Direction: Posterolateral
  • Types:
    • Simple Dislocation
    • Complex Dislocation (with associated fractures)

Initial Management

  • Closed Reduction: Performed promptly after assessing neurovascular status.

Treatment Protocols

  • Simple Dislocations:
    • Early Range of Motion (ROM) initiated within 3 weeks of injury.
  • Persistent Instability:
    • If instability is noted within 30 degrees of full extension, consider acute ligamentous repair.
    • LCL is always repaired, followed by Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) repair if instability persists.

Common Complications

  • Most Common Complication After Closed Treatment: Loss of terminal extension.

“Terrible Triad” Injury

  • Components:
    • Elbow dislocation
    • Radial head fracture
    • Coronoid process fracture
  • Treatment:
    • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) of coronoid process.
    • ORIF or prosthetic replacement of radial head.
    • Lateral and ± medial ligamentous repair.

Persistent Instability Management

  • Options:
    • Hinged external fixator.
    • Transarticular ulnohumeral pinning.
  • Early ROM Protocol:
    • Start with an intraoperative arc of stability.

Positioning for Stability

  • LCL Repaired and MCL Intact:
    • Elbows kept in forearm pronation to increase stability (decreases stress on LCL).
  • LCL Repaired but MCL Deficient:
    • Elbows kept in forearm supination to increase stability (decreases stress on MCL).
  • Both LCL and MCL Repaired:
    • Elbow kept in neutral position.

Option A, B & C: Terrible triad includes Coronoid, elbow dislocation (LCL injury), radial head thus all 3 are incorrect.

Key takeaways:

Structures Involved in terrible triad of elbow:

  • Coronoid Fracture
  • Elbow Dislocation (Lateral Collateral Ligament Injury)
  • Radial Head Fracture

Implications:

  • The combination of these injuries, often resulting from a fracture-dislocation, indicates an unstable elbow.
  • Such instability necessitates surgical stabilization to restore joint integrity.
  • Worse functional outcomes.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a spiral midshaft femur fracture from a high velocity injury presents to the emergency department for evaluation. He is 66 inches tall and weighs 66 kg. The best option for treatment would be:
questions.solution:
Nonoperative Management: Skeletal Traction

  • Indication: Used in adult patients with significant medical comorbidities where surgery is contraindicated.
  • Usage: Temporary measure before surgery; traction should be 15% of body weight (20-40 lb).
  • Complications: Knee stiffness, limb shortening, heterotopic ossification, prolonged hospitalization, respiratory/skin issues, malunion.

Operative Management

  • Standard of Care: Operative stabilization for most femoral shaft fractures, ideally within 24 hours after resuscitation.

Intramedullary Nailing (IM Nailing)

  • Standard for Femoral Shaft Fractures:
    • Benefits: Less exposure, lower infection rates, less quadriceps scarring, lower tensile/shear stresses.
    • Advantages: Maintains fracture hematoma and periosteum; early functional use; high union rates (>95%).
  • Surgical Approach:
    • Antegrade:
      • Positioning: Supine or lateral; either piriformis fossa or greater trochanteric starting point.
      • Consider reaming for better outcomes; all nails should be statically locked.
    • Retrograde:
      • Easier identification of starting point.
      • Relative indications include ipsilateral injuries and bilateral fractures; contraindications include restricted knee motion.

External Fixation

  • Indication: Limited use as definitive treatment; often provisional (damage control).

Plate Fixation

  • Decreasing Use: Due to IM nailing popularity.
  • Advantages:
    • Anatomic reduction possible.
    • Minimal trauma to distant structures.
    • Newer minimally invasive techniques available.
  • Indications:
    • Narrow medullary canal, malunion fractures, obliteration due to infection, proximal/distal extension fractures, and associated vascular injuries

Option A: Long-leg casts are not typically used for adults because of high malunion rates.

Option B: Traction and long leg cast is also not a very feasible option as it will involve prolonged bed rest which increases the chances of DVT, bed sores etc.

Option C: Retrograde IM nailing is not very popular nowadays as it involves opening the fracture site or knee joint which drains fracture hematoma and attracts complications like non-union, infection and knee stiffness.

Option D: An antegrade IM nail with trochanteric starting point would be best choice as it is a minimally invasive procedure and gives good stability and allows early mobilization.

Key takeaways:

Femoral Shaft fractures in adults are managed with an antegrade IM nail with trochanteric starting point as it is a minimally invasive procedure and gives good stability and allows early mobilization.

questions.text: A 44 yr man fell on outstretched hand while jogging in the park. He had pain, deformity and crepitus over the collar bone. Xray shows displaced midshaft clavicle fracture. Clavicle fracture can be treated by all of these except-
questions.solution:
Fracture of the Clavicle

Overview:

  • A common fracture across all age groups, typically caused by a fall on the shoulder or an outstretched hand.

Patho anatomy:

  • Most frequently occurs at the junction of the middle and outer third of the clavicle.
  • Displacement Patterns:
    • Outer Fragment: Displaced medially and downward due to gravity and pectoralis major muscle pull.
    • Inner Fragment: Displaced upward due to the pull of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Diagnosis:

  • Usually straightforward with a history of trauma followed by pain, swelling, and crepitus at the fracture site.

Treatment:

  • Non-Surgical:
    • Clavicle fractures typically heal well even when displaced.
    • Minimal displacement: A triangular sling is sufficient.
    • Active shoulder exercises should begin 10-14 days post-injury once severe pain subsides.
    • For displaced fractures, a figure-of-8 bandage can provide immobilization and pain relief in young adults.
  • Surgical:
    • Indicated for fractures with neurovascular compromise or severe displacement for cosmetic reasons.
    • Treatment involves internal fixation using a plate or nail.

Option A: A figure-of-8 bandage may be applied to a young adult with a displaced fracture. It serves the purpose of immobilisation, and gives pain relief.

Option B: Open reduction and internal fixation is required, either when the fracture is associated with neurovascular deficit.

Option C: some severely displaced fractures, where it may be more of a cosmetic concern. In such cases, the fracture is fixed internally with a plate or a nail(CRIF).

Option D - 'U' slab is used for humerus shaft fractures.

Key takeaways -

Clavicle fracture Management:

  • Minimally Displaced - Triangular sling
  • Displaced Fractures - Figure of 8 Sling
  • Neurovascular deficit - Internal Fixation.

questions.text: All of these are eponyms of distal radius fractures except:
questions.solution:
It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers.


Distal Radius Fracture Types and Mechanisms

  1. Colles Fracture:
    • Involves both extra-articular and intra-articular distal radius fractures with dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shift, and radial shortening.
    • Commonly results in a “dinner fork” deformity.
  2. Smith Fracture (Reverse Colles Fracture):
    • Description:
      • Fracture with volar angulation of the distal radius, creating a “garden spade” deformity.
      • Hand and distal radius are displaced volarly.
  3. Barton Fracture (Volar/Dorsal):
    • Description:
      • A fracture-dislocation or subluxation of the wrist with displacement of the dorsal or volar rim of the distal radius along with the hand and carpus.
      • Volar involvement is more common.
  4. Radial Styloid Fracture (Chauffeur Fracture, Backfire Fracture, Hutchinson Fracture):
    • Description:
      • Avulsion fracture with extrinsic ligaments attached to the styloid fragment.
      • result from a direct blow or compression of scaphoid against the styloid.
  1. Die- Punch fracture:
    • Depressed fracture of the lunate fossa of distal radial articular surface.
    • ORIF is mandatory to prevent post traumatic arthritis and carpal stability.

Option A - Boxer: It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers.

Option B - Die-punch is Depressed fracture of lunate fossa of distal radius.

Option C - Chauffeur's fracture is radial styloid fracture.

Option D - Barton's is Intra-articular fractures through the distal articular surface of the radius; further classified as dorsal or volar depending on displacement.

Key takeaways:

Distal Radius Fracture:

  • Colles Fracture - Dorsal Angulation
  • Smith Fracture - Volar Angulation
  • Barton Fractures - Intra Articular, unstable and usually require surgical intervention.
  • Radial Styloid Fracture/chauffer/huthinson - Avulsion Fracture often involves ligamentous injuries.

questions.text: Identify the name of this angle shown in the image which is used to classify as well as assess prognosis of neck of femur fractures.
questions.solution:
Classification of NOF Fracture:

  1. Anatomical classification –
    1. Sub-capital (Worst prognosis)
    2. Trans-cervical
    3. Basi-cervical (Best prognosis)
  2. Pauwels classification –
    1. Pauwels angle <30 (Best prognosis)
    2. Pauwels angle 30-70
    3. Pauwels angle >70 (Worst prognosis)
  3. Garden’s classification
    1. Trabeculae bending; fracture incomplete
    2. Trabeculae broken; fracture complete but undisplaced
    3. Trabeculae broken and out of alignment; fracture partially displaced
    4. Trabeculae of head parallel with acetabulum; Head completely displaced and rotated.

Option A: Garden Angle doesn’t exist. Garden classification is used for NOF Fractures.

Option B: Neck shaft angle is formed by the femoral shaft and line passing through the centre of the head of the femur. Normal adults have 120-140 degree angles.

Option D: Not Applicable.

Key takeaways -

  • Pauwels classification is based on the angle of inclination of the fracture in relation to the horizontal plane (Pauwels angle). The fractures are divided into three types (type I–III).
  • The more the angle, the more unstable is the fracture, and worse the prognosis.

questions.text: A 35 yr gentleman sustained a humerus mid-shaft fracture following an RTA. All of these treatment modalities can be used to treat this fracture except:
questions.solution:
Screws and k wires alone will not give adequate stability to a long bone like humerus and may lead to non union/ mal union. So it's an incorrect option.

Humerus Fracture Management:

  • Conservative methods
    1. U-slab: (Option A)
      • A plaster slab extending from the base of the neck over the shoulder to the lateral side of the arm and under the elbow to the medial side.
      • Removed after 6-8 weeks once the fracture heals, followed by shoulder exercises.
    2. Hanging Cast
      • Used for lower-third humerus fractures.
      • The weight of the limb and cast provides traction to keep the fracture aligned.
    3. Chest-Arm Bandage
      • Used for humerus fractures in children under five.
      • The arm is strapped to the chest, providing sufficient immobilization.
    4. Functional (Sarmiento) Brace
      • Used for closed humerus fractures that can be managed without surgery.

Operative Methods

Required when closed reduction is not possible or the fracture is unstable. 

  1. ORIF with plates and screws
    • Usually gives high union rates.
    • Allows exploration of radial nerves as well.
    • Weight-bearing tolerance is safe after plate fixation.
  2. CRIF with intramedullary nailing (Option B)
    • Mostly used for segmental or pathologic fractures.
    • Complications include a higher rate of reoperation and shoulder pain.
    • Higher chances of nerve injury as compared to ORIF.
  3. External fixators(Option D)
    • Usually reserved for open/contaminated fractures.

Option C: Screws and k wires alone will not give adequate stability to a long bone like humerus and may lead to non union/ mal union. So it's an incorrect option.

Key takeaways:

Most preferred method of surgical management of humerus shaft fractures is through plate and screws as it gives high rates of union and allows exploration of radial nerves.

Other methods include

  • U Slab / hanging cast for conservative management
  • IM nailing
  • External fixators (in polytrauma, contaminated/infected fractures)

questions.text: Identify the injury of the thumb shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Rolando's Fracture

Definition:

  • A complete, comminuted intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal, typically shaped like a "T" or "Y".

Characteristics:

  • Involves greater force than a Bennett fracture.
  • Can have dorsal and palmar fragments.
  • Sometimes the term ‘Rolando’ is also used to describe a comminuted Bennett fracture.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Unstable fracture requiring immediate treatment.

Treatment Options:

  1. Closed Reduction and Percutaneous Pinning (CRPP):
    • Used for less complex fractures.
  2. Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF):
    • Recommended for more severe fractures or when CRPP is not feasible.
  3. External Fixation:
    • Considered in cases with severe comminution or when other methods are unsuitable.

Immobilization:

  • Post-reduction, immobilize in a thumb spica cast for 3 weeks.

Option A – Rolando fracture - This is a complete articular, ‘T’ or Y’ shaped fracture of the first metacarpal.

Option B – Bennet’s fracture dislocation - It is an oblique intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation or dislocation of the metacarpal.

Option C - Stener lesion occurs when the adductor pollicis aponeurosis becomes interposed between the retracted ulnar collateral ligament in chronic Gamekeeper’s thumb, and this hinders healing.

Key takeaways:

Rolando’s Fracture is A complete, comminuted intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal, typically shaped like a "T" or "Y".

questions.text: A comminuted tibia midshaft fracture can be treated with all of the following modalities through CRIF except:
questions.solution:
Intramedullary Nailing (IM Nailing):

  • Advantages:
    • Preserves periosteal blood supply.
    • Minimizes soft tissue damage.
    • Offers biomechanical control over alignment, translation, and rotation.
  • Locked nails:
    • Locked Nail: (Option A)
      • Provides rotational control.
      • Prevents shortening in comminuted fractures with significant bone loss.
      • Interlocking screws can be removed later to enhance fracture healing.

Flexible Nails (Enders, Rush Rods):

  • Description:
    • Multiple curved intramedullary pins resist angulation and rotation.
    • Causes minimal damage to the medullary circulation.
  • Usage:
    • Recommended for children or adolescents with open growth plates and adults with narrow canals.

External Fixation: (Option C)

  • Indications:
    • Severe open fractures.
    • Complicated closed fractures (e.g., compartment syndrome, head injury, burns).
  • Outcomes:
    • Union rate up to 90%, typically within 3.6 months.
    • Pin tract infection rate of 10% to 15%.

Plates and Screws: (Option B)

  • Indications:
    • Used for fractures extending into the metaphysis or epiphysis.
  • Success and Complications:
    • Success rates as high as 97%.
    • Increased complication rates (infection, wound breakdown, malunion, nonunion) with high-energy injuries.

Key takeaways -

CRIF refers to closed reduction of the fracture without draining the fracture hematoma and internally fixing it with implants. All IM nails (except done in open fractures) are considered CRIF.

Amongst the given options, to fix a comminuted fracture with

  • Plate and screws – Opening of fracture site and reduction needs to be done which is considered as ORIF. Usually done in severely comminuted and intra-articular fractures.
  • External fixator – As the name suggests, they are fixed externally and hence considered CREF. Usually done in emergency, open fractures (OREF) or impending compartment syndrome.

questions.text: AVN of femoral head is a very dreaded complication of femur neck fracture. Amongst the anatomical fracture types, which fracture poses maximum risk for AVN?
questions.solution:
Blood Supply of the Femoral Head and Its Implications Post-Fracture

  • Blood Supply Sources:
    • Medullary Vessels: Arise from the femoral neck and provide essential blood flow to the head.
    • Retinacular Vessels: Enter from the lateral side of the head and are crucial for maintaining head viability.
    • Foveal Vessel: Runs through the ligamentum teres and provides supplementary blood flow to the femoral head.
  • Impact of Femoral Neck Fracture:
    • A fracture through the femoral neck disrupts the medullary and retinacular vessels, cutting off the primary blood supply to the femoral head.
    • The foveal vessel, through the ligamentum teres, becomes the sole source of blood supply to the femoral head.
  • Potential Complications:
    • If the blood supply through the foveal vessel is insufficient, the femoral head may undergo avascular necrosis (AVN).
    • AVN can affect a segment or the entire femoral head, leading to potential non-union of the fracture site.

Option A, B, C & D:

Anatomical classification –

  1. Sub-capital (Worst prognosis) (Option C)
  2. Trans-cervical (Option B)
  3. Basi-cervical (Best prognosis) (Option A)

Maximum chances of avascular necrosis are in subcapital fractures.

Key takeaways -

Maximum chances of avascular necrosis are in subcapital fractures followed by transcervical and basal fractures.

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Common Ankle and Lower Leg Fractures

Pilon Fracture (Option A)

  • Definition: A comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia, often extending through the fibula.
  • Prevalence: Represents 7% to 10% of all tibia fractures.
  • Mechanism of Injury: Usually caused by high-energy impacts such as falls from height or motor vehicle accidents.
  • Complications: High risk of associated injuries due to the nature of the trauma; thorough evaluation is required to rule out other concomitant injuries.

Pott's Fracture (Option B)

  • Definition: A bimalleolar ankle fracture involving both the medial and lateral malleoli.
  • Mechanism of Injury: Caused by various bending and twisting forces impacting the ankle joint.
  • Classification: Used as a general term for any fracture involving both malleoli.

Maisonneuve Fracture (Option C)

  • Definition: An ankle injury with a fracture of the proximal third of the fibula.
  • Mechanism of Injury: Results from a pronation–external rotation injury, rather than direct trauma to the fibula.
  • Clinical Importance: Must be differentiated from direct trauma to avoid misdiagnosis and improper treatment.

Cotton's Fracture (Option D)

  • Definition: A trimalleolar ankle fracture involving the medial malleolus, lateral malleolus, and posterior aspect of the tibia.

Key takeaways -

  • Pott's fracture: Bimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Cotton's fracture: Trimalleolar ankle fracture.
  • Massonaise's fracture: the neck of the fibula fracture.
  • Pilon fracture: It is a comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia through the fibula

questions.text: All of the following are the eponymous fractures of the meta-tarsals except:
questions.solution:
Common Foot Fractures

Aviator's Fracture – Option D

  • Definition: Fracture of the neck of the talus.
  • Historical Context: Referred to as "Aviator’s astragalus," this term originates from the impact of a rudder bar in a crashing airplane on the plantar aspect of the foot, resulting in a talar neck fracture.

Jones Fracture (Option A)

  • Definition: An avulsion fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal.
  • Injury Classification: Zone 2 injuries are classified as Jones fractures.
  • Mechanism of Injury: Result from adduction or inversion of the forefoot, causing tensile stress along the lateral border of the metatarsal.
  • Treatment Options: Controversial; options include:
    • Weight-bearing or non-weight-bearing in a short leg cast.
    • Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF).
  • Union Concerns: There is often a concern regarding the union of this type of fracture.

March Fracture (Option B)

  • Definition: A fatigue fracture of the shaft of the 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.
  • Mechanism of Injury: Often occurs due to repetitive stress from long hours of walking or running, particularly in military recruits.
  • Relation to Stress Fractures: March fractures are a type of stress fracture, commonly seen in the necks of the second and third metatarsals and the proximal fifth metatarsal.

Dancer's Fracture – Option C

  • Definition: A fracture of the distal shaft of the 5th metatarsal.
  • Injury Classification: Occurs beyond Zone 3.
  • Usually oblique or spiral type fracture due to twisting movements during dancing.

Key takeaways -

  • Aviator's fracture: Fracture of neck of the talus.
  • Jone's fracture: Avulsion fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal.
  • March fracture: Fatigue fracture of the shaft of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.
  • Dancer's fracture – Fracture of distal shaft of 5th

questions.text: A 65 yr old fell this morning in her bathroom after which she is not able to bear weight on right side and has severe pain. She was brought to the orthopaedic department for further management. PBH AP view shoes right NOF fracture with pre-existing hip joint arthritis. Best plan of management for her would be?
questions.solution:
Operative Treatment Principles for Fractures:

Fracture Reduction

  • Reduction Maneuver:
    • Perform hip flexion with gentle traction and external rotation to disengage the fragments.
    • Follow with slow extension and internal rotation to achieve reduction.
    • Confirm reduction with AP and lateral imaging.
  • Guidelines for Acceptable Reduction:
    • AP View: Valgus or anatomical alignment should be observed.
    • Lateral View: Maintain anteversion while avoiding posterior translation of the fracture surfaces.

Internal Fixation

  • Multiple Screw Fixation: Option A
    • Most accepted method; screws should cross the fracture site for compression.
    • Typically, three parallel screws are used. Additional screws do not enhance stability and may penetrate the joint.
    • Configuration: Screws should be arranged in an inverted triangular configuration with one screw adjacent to the inferior femoral neck and another to the posterior femoral neck.
  • Sliding-Screw and Side Plate Devices: Option D
    • If utilized, a second pin or screw should be placed superiorly to control rotation during screw insertion.
    • These devices improve resistance to shear forces, particularly in high Pauwel angle fractures.

Prosthetic Replacement Option C

  • Advantages Over Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF):
    • Allows for faster full weight-bearing.
    • Eliminates risks of nonunion, osteonecrosis, and failure of fixation (over 20% to 40% of ORIF cases may require secondary surgery).
  • Disadvantages:
    • More extensive procedure with greater blood loss.

Primary Total Hip Replacement: Option B

  • Recent interest in total hip replacement for acute treatment of displaced femoral neck fractures has increased especially in cases with pre-existing arthritis.
  • Studies indicate better functional results compared to hemiarthroplasty and internal fixation.
  • Eliminates potential acetabular erosion associated with hemiarthroplasty.

Option A: Fixation with Cancellous screws is done when fracture reduction is possible in <60 years patients.

Option C: Bipolar hemiarthroplasty is prefered in >60 years patients without existing arthritis.

Option D: Fixation with dynamic screw is done when fracture reduction is not possible in <60 years patients.

Key takeaways:

Neck of femur fracture management:

  • If age is less than 60 yrs - Fixation with Screws or DHS
  • If age is more than 60 yrs without pre-existing arthritis and not very active lifestyle - Bipolar hemiarthroplasty
  • If age is more than 60 yrs with pre-existing arthritis and active lifestyle - Total hip replacement.
